item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

io9:

Hey not to call you a dumbass, but he is learning Java, and I’d expect someone like you to notice that. Why else would he have trouble compling a program, and why is the class called “First”. Fucking genius.

And since when do you know every single aspect of programming and can code in Java flawlessly? You can’t even make a working loader using applet stub. “Fucking genius.”

item.title: This is confusing, why I keep getting this error
item.dc:creator: @ilyaostr9 io9
item.description:
@ilyaostr9 wrote:

Try to see if any of this went wrong:

  1. Did you follow my tutorial?
  2. If you did, then you’re a dumbass, however, if you didn’t, try naming your file “First.java”. Also, make sure you use “cd” to get to the directory where the java file is located.

[quote=“pplsuqbawlz, post:2, topic:66751”]Hey dude, not to criticize… But learn java and learn the meaning of “CASE-SENSITIVE”.

try: javac First.java

Make sure the classfile is named First.java. also make sure you traverse your directories correctly.[/quote]
Hey not to call you a dumbass, but he is learning Java, and I’d expect someone like you to notice that. Why else would he have trouble compling a program, and why is the class called “First”. Fucking genius.

Read full topic

item.title: This is confusing, why I keep getting this error
item.dc:creator: @Eh_Pretty_Easy Eh Pretty Easy
item.description:
@Eh_Pretty_Easy wrote:

I made a first.java file and put this in it

class First { public static void main(String[] args) { System.out.println("George Bush is a fucking retard"); } }
So that it would pop up the text Hello world!, then I tried to do the javac first from command prompt, but I keep getting this.

[code]
C:>javac first
error: Class names, ‘first’, are only accepted if annotation processing is expli
citly requested
1 error

C:>[/code]
Why I keep getting that?

Read full topic
